Posts.Content: On Apr 24, 2017 2:17 AM pgjudy200 wrote: I have a Power of Attorney and that's how I'm able to go to the imaging company and get her reports before we see the doctor.  My daughter is not interested in seeing them or knowing what's of interest in them.  These reports are never published on the patient's portal so the patient never sees them unless they request a copy. You have my interest peeked now about why they claim the mass will never be removed.  I know 20-30 years ago you would hear that doctor's didn't want to "disturb" the tumor for fear of spreading the cancer.  But, I believe we've come a long way since then.  Had I been with her at this last visit I would have asked if they plan to do an MRI since the report said the only way they could determine the size of the mass was with an MRI.  I asked my daughter if an MRI was mentioned and she said no.  But she had no idea why I was asking.  I don't want her to get to the point where she doesn't have confidence in her doctor by my asking so many questions.  It's like being between a rock and a hard place. If your daughter is 61 you must be ~80?  You sure have a lot of energy to devote to your daughter's health matters at your own advanced age.  Not to mention; computer saavy. Kudos to you!

Posts.Content: LOL, you have received the craziest responses! There are certainly a lot of spam bots out there! Who cares if she's lying.  Like someone else said, don't play into it.  Either you're lying or she's lying....so take it from there.  People DO lie about having cancer all the time.  I'm sure you have read about that woman that faked a 2+ year cancer journey; online. People lie about crazy stuff; even cancer. If you don't feel like you believe her, then don't. As you stated; she looks fine for having gone through 3 rounds of chemo in a few weeks.
